context_bundle.summary: First-time user onboarding for PhiSHRI door system - start here if you're new to the index

onboarding.quick_start: Welcome to PhiSHRI! You're in the right place. Read this door, then INDEX.json, then navigate by door codes.
common_patterns: Step 2: Identify door code for your topic (D05=deployment, W115=messaging, S05=secrets)
Step 4: Follow prerequisites and related_doors for complete context
Step 5: Read full_context_path PhiDEX guide if needed
OPTIMIZATION: Read multiple related doors in parallel (single message) to reduce overhead by 30-50%
known_errors: DON'T search with grep/find - door codes are semantic, use them directly
DON'T use training data - read actual door files for current info
DON'T skip prerequisites - they're foundational knowledge
DON'T ignore INDEX.json - it shows what exists and where
DON'T read doors sequentially when you can read them in parallel - system overhead is per-message, not per-file

question_1.q: What are you trying to learn about?

deployment.answer: Read doors D05-D14 for deployment patterns. Start with D05SILENT_INSTALL for basics.
deployment.parallel_read_tip: Read D05, D06, D07, D08, D13 in a single message with parallel Read calls to reduce overhead by 30-50%

agent_communication.answer: Read doors W115-W131 for agent communication. Start with W115MESSAGE_QUEUE.

security.answer: Read doors S01-S18 for security patterns. Start with S01SEC for overview.

workflows.answer: Read doors W01-W131 for workflow patterns. Start with W01COORD for coordination.

architecture.answer: Read doors R01-R16 for architecture patterns. Start with R01MULTI for multi-agent systems.

tools.answer: Read doors T01-T27 and 800-840 for development tools. Start with T01MCP for MCP servers.

errors.answer: Read doors E01-E13 for error handling patterns. Start with E05RETRY.

question_2.q: How experienced are you with this codebase?

beginner.answer: Read HOW_TO_USE.md first, then INDEX.json, then start with prerequisite doors (lower numbers like D01, W01, S01)

intermediate.answer: You know the basics. Use INDEX.json to find topics, read door JSONs directly, follow related_doors for deeper context.
recommended_path: Jump to topic doors (D05, W115, S05, etc.)
Read PhiDEX guides for implementation details

expert.answer: You know the drill. Door codes are semantic. Read what you need, skip prerequisites you know, contribute new doors to expand coverage.
recommended_path: Contribute new doors when you find gaps
Add to PhiDEX guides for source material

system_architecture.description: PhiSHRI (Semantic Hash Repository Index) is a structured knowledge base with 236+ 'doors' (JSON context files) organized by category. Each door contains curated information extracted from PhiDEX source documentation with zero hallucinations.
design_principles: Semantic door codes: Names describe content (D05SILENT_INSTALL, W115MESSAGE_QUEUE)
Prerequisite chains: Doors link to foundational knowledge
Related doors graph: Navigate by topic relationships
Zero hallucinations: All content from PhiDEX sources
Fast lookup: < 100ms direct file reads, no searching required
navigation_methods: hash_code_lookup: Know the door code, read directly
natural_language_query: Use INDEX.json descriptions to find doors
error_pattern_matching: Error doors link to solutions
prerequisite_chain_loading: Follow dependencies for complete context

example_1.scenario: Need to deploy software silently to 500 machines
optimal_flow: 2. Read D05, D06, D07, D08, D13 in PARALLEL (single message with 5 Read calls)
example_1.result: Complete deployment strategy with specific commands and best practices
example_1.efficiency_note: Parallel reading reduces overhead from ~26K tokens to ~13K tokens (50% savings)

example_2.scenario: Agents need to communicate via file-based IPC
optimal_flow: 1. Read 000START.json â†’ Find agent communication guidance
2. Read W115, W116, W117, W118 in PARALLEL (single message with 4 Read calls)
3. Analyze message queue, IPC, file-based patterns together
4. Check full_context_path for PhiSync detailed guides if needed
example_2.result: File-based IPC implementation with polling, correlation IDs, dead letter queues
example_2.efficiency_note: Parallel reading saves one message round-trip

optimal_flow: 2. Read S01, S09, S10, S11, S12 in PARALLEL (single message with 5 Read calls)
3. Analyze security patterns, RBAC, JWT, CORS, CSRF together
example_3.result: Complete API security implementation with RBAC, JWT, CORS, CSRF protection
example_3.efficiency_note: Parallel reading achieves comprehensive security coverage in minimal time

q1.question: Why not just use grep/search to find information?
q1.answer: Door codes are semantic - they tell you what they contain. D05 is the 5th deployment door about silent installation. No searching needed! Searching wastes time and finds too many irrelevant results.

q2.question: Why not use my training data knowledge?
q2.answer: Training data may be outdated or not specific to this codebase. PhiSHRI doors contain curated, current information extracted from PhiDEX source documentation. Zero hallucinations guarantee.

q3.question: How do I know which door to read first?
q3.answer: Check the prerequisites field in any door. Lower-numbered doors (D01, W01, S01) are usually foundational. Follow the prerequisite chain for complete understanding.

q4.question: What if a door references a PhiDEX path that doesn't exist?
q4.answer: The door JSON has the key information even without the full guide. If needed, use Glob to find alternate paths: **/*ENTERPRISE*.md or check /PHIiSRHI/PhiDEX/ vs /PhiDEX/ directories.

q5.question: Can I contribute new doors?
q5.answer: Yes! Follow the zero hallucinations protocol: Extract information from PhiDEX source files only. Use the door template structure. Increment door codes sequentially. Update INDEX.json with new counts.

q6.question: Should I read doors one at a time or in parallel?
q6.answer: ALWAYS read multiple related doors in parallel (single message with multiple Read tool calls). System overhead is per-message, not per-file. Reading 5 doors in 1 message uses ~13K overhead. Reading 5 doors across 3 messages uses ~26K overhead. Parallel reading saves 30-50% tokens and is 2-3x faster.

q7.question: Can I skip 000START if I already know the door codes?
q7.answer: EXPERT MODE: Yes! If you know the door code patterns (D05-D14=deployment, W115-W131=messaging, S01-S18=security), go directly to doors. Saves ~3K tokens and 3-5 seconds. Trade-off: You miss related_doors recommendations and optimization tips. Beginners should always read 000START first.

q8.question: Should I read INDEX.json or 000START for onboarding?
q8.answer: INDEX.json (1.5K tokens) gives category overview and door counts. 000START.json (3.2K tokens) gives full onboarding with examples and FAQs. For quick category scan: INDEX.json. For first-time comprehensive guide: 000START.json. Saves ~1.7K tokens if you just need the overview.

q9.question: How many doors should I read for a quick answer vs comprehensive coverage?
q9.answer: MINIMAL (2-3 doors, 4 seconds): Core topic only. COMPREHENSIVE (5-7 doors, 6 seconds): Includes related_doors for full picture. Example deployment: Minimal=D05,D06 (silent install + enterprise). Comprehensive=D05,D06,D07,D08,D13 (+ GPO, Autopilot, network optimization).

tweak_1_parallel_reading.description: Read multiple doors in single message with parallel Read calls
tweak_1_parallel_reading.example: Read D05, D06, D07, D08, D13 in one message instead of sequential reads
tweak_1_parallel_reading.when_to_use: Always - no downside to parallel reading

tweak_2_expert_mode.description: Skip 000START if you know door code patterns
tweak_2_expert_mode.when_to_use: Repeat users, known topics, time-critical queries
tweak_2_expert_mode.trade_off: Miss related_doors recommendations and optimization tips

tweak_3_core_only_reading.description: Read only 2 core doors instead of 5 comprehensive doors (80/20 rule)
tweak_3_core_only_reading.principle: 80% of the information in 20% of the doors
tweak_3_core_only_reading.when_to_use: Quick answers, just-in-time learning, can iterate with follow-ups
tweak_3_core_only_reading.trade_off: Less comprehensive initial answer, might need to come back for specialized info
how_to_decide: Check prerequisites field: Lower numbers = more foundational
Check related_doors field: Read core first, extended later if needed
Core doors contain essential patterns, extended doors are specialized

tweak_4_index_vs_000start.description: Use INDEX.json instead of 000START for door discovery
tweak_4_index_vs_000start.when_to_use: Quick lookup, just need category â†’ door code mapping, doing research not onboarding
tweak_4_index_vs_000start.when_000start_better: First-time users, need guidance on optimal flow, want system architecture understanding
tweak_4_index_vs_000start.index_provides: Essential mapping: categories â†’ door codes â†’ descriptions, door counts
tweak_4_index_vs_000start.000start_adds: Interactive guide Q&A, detailed flow examples, FAQ section, welcome message, architecture explanation
tweak_4_index_vs_000start.combined_optimization: INDEX.json + core doors only (D05, D06) = ~15K tokens, 60% reduction from baseline

tweak_5_batch_request.description: User specifies exact door codes in initial request (eliminates discovery phase)
tweak_5_batch_request.principle: Skip navigation files entirely, go straight to content
how_to_build_habit: 1. First time: Use 000START to discover door codes
2. Take note of codes for topics you care about
3. Future sessions: Request doors directly by code

door_code_cheat_sheet.deployment: D05=Silent Install, D06=Enterprise, D07=GPO, D08=Autopilot, D13=Network
door_code_cheat_sheet.messaging: W115=Message Queue, W116=IPC, W117=File IPC, W118=Request/Response

tweak_5_batch_request.trade_off: Requires memorizing door codes, might miss discovering related doors, best for power users
